Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Proposal: Development of Digital Models of Minerals and Rocks for Online Geoscience Classes
Award.AbstractNarration: The sudden shift to remote online teaching due to the COVID-19 crisis has especially impacted laboratory classes. Petrologists and mineralogists have created three-dimensional models of rock and mineral specimens, which are available online. The commercial site that hosts these does not include a searchable database. This project will create a searchable database and copy the models to a university-hosted server. Additional specimens will be added.<br/><br/>Image-processing has become routine, which has made it practical to create visually and topologically accurate representation of geologic specimens. Teachers have been creating these images and putting them on a commercial website for the use of the wider community. The problem is that this collection of hundreds of virtual specimens is not searchable. The PIs will create a searchable database with the specific metadata that will be useful to science teachers. Moreover, the virtual specimens will also be copied to a university-hosted server, which will assure access for years. Additional specimens will be imaged. This virtual collection has become vital in the time of COVID-19 and a shift to widespread online instruction.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project successfully delivered a comprehensive catalog of digital 3D models of minerals and rocks on Sketchfab.com to facilitate online instruction during and after the COVID-19 pandemic. By the end of the project over five thousand samples were identified and over two hundred individuals had accessed the DEMON 3D catalog. Two undergraduate students and two graduate students assisted in the preparation of the catalog and quality-controlled the models, as well as assigning them to different categories.

The DEMON 3D catalog was accompanied by a series of short online videos demonstrating how potential model makers could photograph samples and then construct models for their own classes and for the broader community. Each video has at least two hundred views and a couple have over two thousand each.

Finally, the DEMON 3D catalog and the principles behind it were disseminated to the geoscience community through several email listservs and a short article in GSA Today. The article explained the need for such models and their potential uses, pros, and cons. It also made a case for the continued use of models in a post-pandemic teaching environment as they better facilitate online instruction for non-traditional students and to those geoscience departments without access to large and diverse collections of superior quality.
